item.title: Travis CI and Codecov
item.description: <p>I ended up at OpenShift because I was looking for a free Jenkins solution, Jenkins being the CI tool with which I'm most familiar. But, I've since discovered <a href="https://travis-ci.org/Azuaron/wp2jbake">Travis CI</a>, which is incredibly open-source friendly and perfect for this plugin project. Along with that, I discovered <a href="https://codecov.io/github/Azuaron/wp2jbake?ref=master">Codecov</a> which stores code coverage statistics (calculated with <a href="http://eclemma.org/jacoco/trunk/">Jacoco</a>). With both of these up and running, there's no need for the Jenkins solution on OpenShift.</p> <p>So, what to do with OpenShift? With all three gears open, I can get a SonarQube instance running (one gear for the server, one gear for the unused scalable web front, and one gear for the database). That being said, having Travis and Codecov running significantly reduces the need to get that running, so it's been put on the back burner for the moment.</p>

The fax machine is how old?
item.description: <p><img src="http://azuaron.github.io/imagesBain_improved_facsimile_1850.png" alt="Alexander Bain's fax machine, 1843" /> Alexander Bain's fax machine, 1843{caption}</p> <p>In 1843, Alexander Bain applied for the first patent on a "chemical telegram" which could record "lines and ticks" and send them over the telegraph. By 1846, he could sketch and send images. Read the complete history of the telegraph at <a href="http://www.todayifoundout.com/index.php/2014/11/shockingly-old-history-fax-machine/">Today I Found Out</a>.</p>

item.title: The Earth in 100,000,000 years
item.description: <p><img src="http://azuaron.github.io/imagesamasia.jpg" alt="Amasia" /> Image from Ross Mitchell, Nature{caption}</p> <p>Most high school students learn that the Earth used to have only a single continent: Pangaea. In 100 million years, the continents are <a href="http://discovermagazine.com/2012/jul-aug/06-earth-look-like-this-in-100-000-000-ad">drifting toward</a> <a href="http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v482/n7384/full/nature10800.html">the formation of a new supercontinent</a>: <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/80beats/2012/02/09/americas-europe-asia-amasia-the-next-supercontinent-to-form-in-arctic/">Amasia</a>.</p>
